item.title: R and RStudio tricks and shortcuts
item.description: In this post I will try to consetrete nice shortcuts that I tend to use or I wish to use more ofter. I will try to keep it updated! Multiple Cursors Using RStudio as our IDE, we can edit multiple places at the same time with “multiple cursors”. We can create multiple cursors by: Ctrl+Alt and use the keyboard up/down arrows In addition, you can use Ctrl + Alt + Shift and the keyboard arrows to skip rows, postion, etc.

item.title: Creating functions in R
item.description: Building functions are one of the main building blocks in programming and in writing reproducible, easy to understand and readable code. In addition, it allows you to write what you need in a more efficient way and to detect errors more easily. Besides these important things, in most cases, your code will run faster. After I convinced you, I hope, we can start learning how to write functions. Functions can do everything that you can code and ideally whenever you’re writing the same code more than twice you’ll make a function out of it.

item.title: Working with files and folders outside R
item.description: When running an analysis, sometimes the need to change/create files and folder in our computer arises. For example when we might want to download many files at once to a specific folder or when we need to save temporary files of our analysis for later use to free our RAM. Whenever we open an R session, R creates a temporary folder and will delete it when we close the R session.

item.title: Converting BibTeX files to md files
item.description: This is my first post! YAY! While wondering around the amazing world of blog writing with blogdown package I had to choose a theme to work with. For now, I’ve chosen the hugo academic theme due to recommendations over the web and it’s so called easy interface and “out of the box” utilities. The first problem that I had to tackle was how to post my publications. Thus to convert my library of publications which were saved as one BibTeX file.
